questions.question_text:
You restore and recover your database to a new host by using an existing RMAN open database backup.
Which step must you perform next?

choices.A: Execute catproc.sql to recompile invalid PL/SQL modules.
choices.D: Use the RMAN set newname and switch commands to switch to new files.
choices.B: Open the database with the resetlogs option.
choices.C: Set a new database identifier (DBID) for the newly restored database.

discussion.content: I agree B is the correct
A B is the correct. agree on your answers
F is wrong, in 12c information is stored in SYSAUX tablespace

choices.E: Unified auditing is enabled by setting the audit_trail parameter to db, extended.
choices.D: Audit records are created only for the DML and DDL operations performed on database objects.
choices.C: Audit records are created for all users except sys.
choices.B: Unified auditing is enabled by executing make-fins_rdbms.mk uniaud_onioracle ORACLE_HOME=SORACLE_HOME.
choices.F: A unified audit trail resides in a read-only table in the audsys schema in the system tablespace.
choices.A: A unified audit trail captures audit information from unified audit policies and audit settings.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about unified auditing?

Your database is running in archivelog mode. You are taking a backup of your database by using RMAN with a recovery catalog. Because of a media failure, one of the data files and all the control files are lost.
Examine the steps to recover the database:
1.Restore the control files by using the RMAN restore controlfile command.
2.Mount the database.
3.Restore the data files by using the RMAN restore database command.
4.Open the database with the resetlogs option.
5.Recover the data files by using the RMAN recover using backup controlfile command.
6.Start the database instance in nomount state.
7.Connect to the target database by using a recovery catalog.
8.Open the database.
9.Restore the data file.
10.Recover the data file.
Identify the required steps in the correct order.

discussion.content: Because all controlfiles are lost, you need to open resetlogs. See documentation: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/BRADV/rcmcomre.htm#BRADV89763
I woud choose for answer A

questions.answer_description:
The awrddrpt.sql report is the Automated Workload Repository Compare Period Report. The awrddrpt.sql script is located in the $ORACLE_HOME/rdbms/admin directory.
Incorrect Answers:
A: Compare Period ADDM is used to perform a high-level comparison of one workload replay to its capture or to another replay of the same capture. Only workload replays that contain at least 5 minutes of database time can be compared using this report.
questions.question_text:
You notice a performance change in your production Oracle 12c database. You want to know which change caused this performance difference.
Which method or feature should you use?

choices.D: Taking a new snapshot and comparing it with a preserved snapshot

discussion.content:
The answer is A 
Compare Period ADDM report
The Compare Period ADDM compares the performance of the database server in two time periods, and returns a report describing the performance changes and the root origin of the changes.
it's controversial one, between A and B

choices.D: It retrieves all versions of rows that exist in a time interval, including the start time and end time.
choices.E: It can be used to retrieve the SQL that is required to undo a row change and the user responsible for the change.
choices.C: It can be used only if Flashback Data Archive is enabled for a table.
choices.A: The result of a query can be used as part of a DML statement.
choices.B: It can be used to create views.

discussion.content:
D. It retrieves all versions of rows that exist in a time interval, including the start time and end time.
E. It can be used to retrieve the SQL that is required to undo a row change and the user responsible for the change.
B and D. Not E because that is Flashback Transaction Query

comments.content: May I know which column displays the user responsible for that change? What will happen if that user is dropped from the database?

discussion.content: I agree D E. ive read this from by book 063 SYBEX in chapter 8

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about Flashback Version Query?
